intro: Galium puncticulosum var. pilosum, commonly known as hairy wood-ears, is a low-growing perennial herb native to parts of Asia. It features slender, ascending stems covered in fine, soft hairs, giving it a distinctive appearance. The plant produces small, white or pale green flowers arranged in clusters, which bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are alternate, ovate to elliptic in shape, and often have a hairy texture. This species is typically found in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors or rocky slopes.
